title: 108_s2969
content: The Act may be cited as the "Fair Gift Card Act" and includes definitions for clarity. The "Fair Gift Card Act" defines terms such as gift certificates, store gift cards, and general-use prepaid cards. Gift certificates are usable at a single merchant or affiliated group, issued in a specified amount, purchased on a prepaid basis, and honored for goods or services. The "Fair Gift Card Act" defines terms like gift certificates, store gift cards, and general-use prepaid cards. Store gift cards are usable at a single merchant or affiliated group, issued in a specified amount, purchased on a prepaid basis, and honored for goods or services. A general-use prepaid card, as defined by the "Fair Gift Card Act," is issued by a bank or financial institution, usable at multiple unaffiliated merchants or ATMs, and can be loaded with a requested amount on a prepaid basis. The term "general-use prepaid card" refers to a card issued by a bank or financial institution, usable at various merchants or ATMs, loaded with a requested amount on a prepaid basis, excluding debit cards linked to a demand deposit or share draft account. It also excludes gift certificates, store gift cards, and general-use prepaid cards used solely for telephone services or associated with a demand deposit, checking, savings, or similar account. The term "debit card" is defined under the Fair Credit Reporting Act. "Financial institution" is also defined under the same Act. "Dormancy fee" and "inactivity charge or fee" refer to penalties for non-use of gift certificates or prepaid cards. "Service fee" is a periodic charge for a prepaid card. The term "service fee" refers to a periodic charge for holding or using a gift certificate, store card, or prepaid general use card. A "licensed money transmitter" is a person who sells payment instruments or transmits money within the United States or abroad. Regulation of unfair and deceptive acts and practices in connection with gift cards. Regulation prohibits imposition of fees on gift certificates, store gift cards, or prepaid cards, except for a fee of $1 on cards with remaining value of $5 or less after 24 months of inactivity. Regulation prohibits fees on gift certificates, store gift cards, or prepaid cards, except for a $1 fee on cards with remaining value of $5 or less after 24 months of inactivity. The holder can reload or add value to the card if requirements are met, including clear disclosure of fees in 10-point font. The regulation prohibits fees on gift certificates, store gift cards, or prepaid cards, except for a $1 fee on cards with remaining value of $5 or less after 24 months of inactivity. The issuer must inform the purchaser of any charges or fees before the purchase, regardless of the method of purchase. Exclusions include gift certificates distributed as part of a program with no monetary exchange, or those that expire within 30 days of sale below face value for specific purposes. It is generally illegal to sell gift certificates, store gift cards, or prepaid cards with expiration dates, except if the expiration date is at least 5 years from the purchase date. Expiration terms must be clearly disclosed in 10-point font and all capital letters. The Act and regulations established under it do not override State laws on charges, fees, and expiration dates of gift certificates, store gift cards, or prepaid cards. Enforcement provisions are also included. SEC. 5. ENFORCEMENT. Violations of this Act will be treated as violations of rules defining unfair or deceptive acts under the Federal Trade Commission Act. The Federal Trade Commission will enforce this Act with the same powers and duties as under the Federal Trade Commission Act. Individuals still have the right to enforce State laws on unfair or deceptive acts.
